io.aesy.datasize

Class DataSize

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.aesy.datasize.DataSize
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<DataSize>

    public final class DataSize
extends Object
implements Comparable<DataSize>, Serializable
    A DataSize object models a quantity of digital information measured in bits or bytes.

    It features a number of convenience methods, such as DataSize#format, DataSize#parse and DataSize#toNaturalUnit, that make use of separate implementations at the cost of versability. Use the dedicated classes if the convenience featured in this class isn't enough for your usecase.

    All methods featuring comparisons of any kind, including DataSize#equals, compare the value of the DataSize objects as ByteUnit.BYTE, meaning that DataSize.of(1000, ByteUnit.BYTE) and DataSize.of(1, ByteUnit.SI.KILOBYTE) are considered equal.

    No measures are taken to ensure that values can be represented as whole bits, hence DataSize.of(1.01, ByteUnts.BYTE) is perfectly valid even though it make little to no sense. If this isn't desirable, it has to be enforced externally.

    Example usage: 
    
 DataSize bytes1 = DataSize.of(1000, ByteUnit.BYTE);
 DataSize bytes2 = DataSize.of(1, ByteUnit.SI.KILOBYTE);

 assertTrue(bytes1.equals(bytes2));
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • format

        public static String format(DataSize datasize,
                            String format)
        Formats a DataSize object based on a format description to produce a nicely formatted string. The formatted output produced by this is of the form "#.## <unit>", where "<unit>" is the abbreviation of the unit associated with this instance.

        The way the number is formatted is based on Locale.getDefault(Locale.Category.FORMAT).

        Parameters:
        datasize - The DataSize to format
        Returns:
        The formatted DataSize string
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the DataSize object is null

      • parse

        public static DataSize parse(String input)
                      throws ParseException
        Parses an input string to produce a DataSize object.

        The method expects a string od the form "2.42 kB" or "2.42 kilobyte". Unit names in plural are accepted.

        The method is locale aware and uses Locale.getDefault(Category.Format) to determine the format of the expected number. Locale may be changed between calls to this method. If a specific locale is desired, see LenientDataSizeParser.

        The parsing performed by this method is case insensitive and ignores unexpected whitespace characters.

        SI units will always be preferred over JEDEC units, meaning that DataSize.parse("1 kB") will result in an object equivalent to DataSize.of(1, ByteUnit.SI.KILOBYTE). If this behavior is not desired, see a DataSizeParser implementation that fits your usecase.

        Parameters:
        input - The input string to parse
        Returns:
        The produced DataSize object
        Throws:
        ParseException - If the input string could not be parsed
        IllegalArgumentException - If the input string is null
        See Also:
        LenientDataSizeParser

      • add

        public DataSize add(DataSize other)
        Returns a new DataSize object whose value is greater than this according to the value of the given DataSize object.

        The resulting object will be represented by the same unit as this object.

        Parameters:
        other - The given DataSize object
        Returns:
        A new DataSize object

      • subtract

        public DataSize subtract(DataSize other)
        Returns a new DataSize object whose value is lesser than this according to the value of the given DataSize object.

        The resulting objects' value is capped at zero and will be represented by the same unit as this object.

        Parameters:
        other - The given DataSize object
        Returns:
        A new DataSize object

      • increment

        public DataSize increment()
        Returns a new DataSize object whose value is 1 greater than this.

        The resulting object will be represented using the same unit as this.

        Returns:
        A new DataSize object

      • decrement

        public DataSize decrement()

        The resulting objects' value is capped at zero and will be represented using the same unit as this.

        Returns:
        A new DataSize object

      • toUnit

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        A new DataSize object

      • toNaturalUnit

        public DataSize toNaturalUnit()
        Converts this object to a more human readable unit.

        The resulting unit will be of the same standard, such as SI, JEDEC or IEC as this object, unless this objects' unit is ByteUnit.BYTE by which the resulting unit may be of any available ByteUnit type.

        Returns:
        A new DataSize object that is equal to this.
        See Also:
        SimpleNaturalDataSizeConverter

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(DataSize other)
        Compares this object with the specified object for order.

        Returns a negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object.

        Two DataSize objects are considered equal if both of their values as ByteUnit.BYTE are exactly equal.

        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable<DataSize>
        Parameters:
        other - The object to be compared
        Returns:
        A negative integer, zero, or a positive integer as this object is less than, equal to, or greater than the specified object
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified object is null

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Object other)
        Indicates whether some other object is "equal to" this one.

        Two objects are considered equal if and only if:

        • neither object is null
        • they both are, or inherit from, DataSize
        • they have the same value when converted to ByteUnit.BYTE
        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        other - The reference object to compare with
        Returns:
        true If this object is equal to the other object; false otherwise

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns a string representation of this object.

        The string representation is concise and easy to read - the value will be rounded off and the unit will be represented by its' abbreviation. The value will use american format.

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        A string representation of this object
